posts.name: AllenGregoryIV
posts.cooked:
One of our offseason projects has been reorganizing our small parts storage.

We evaluated a range of options, from those we had previously used to those we had observed other teams using.

Be modular and easy to transport. We often move our equipment in the back of our school bus or in the back of vans. So we didn’t want to build out a super pit or anything like that.

We wanted them to be durable. We have had numerous issues with various plastic storage cases over the years, ranging from latches breaking to the entire lid cracking.

Easy to label and keep organized. We wanted to label each container and have maps indicating the location of each compartment, etc.

Be customizable for each application. There are many great containers and storage cases, but you can’t always customize their compartments to suit your needs. We decided that using something like Gridfinity, which allows for all the customization we needed, was the best option.

We want to be able to take each storage box to another team’s pit, or to a table, or put it on our cart, etc. This eliminated something like Milwaukee packout drawers and the like.

We wanted each case to store a large number of items. We didn’t want to have to have overflow storage for all our fasteners and parts that we store in these cases.

Durham 123-95: Steel Deep Compartment Boxes (we buy them empty) There are several places to buy these; MSC was the cheapest we found.

There are several places to buy these; MSC was the cheapest we found.

Value Collection BDNA-80320-1B: 4 Drawer Small Parts Slide Rack

Modified Gridfinity grids and bins.

image 777×594 32.1 KB image 905×667 40.4 KB image 722×915 74.6 KB

image 777×594 32.1 KB

We modified the drawer units in several ways. We added corner protectors that also let them stack nicely.

Corner Protectors - https://www.penn-elcom.com/us/small-plastic-black-chevron-stacking-corner-c1567 We just matched drilled these to the drawer units and riveted with ⅛” rivets. image 505×457 22.7 KB

Corner Protectors - https://www.penn-elcom.com/us/small-plastic-black-chevron-stacking-corner-c1567 We just matched drilled these to the drawer units and riveted with ⅛” rivets. image 505×457 22.7 KB

image 505×457 22.7 KB

image 505×457 22.7 KB

Recessed Folding Handles - https://amzn.to/4mBUhhP We used an M12 cutoff tool to cut out holes in the sides of each drawer unit and then riveted with 3/16” rivets. image 556×416 77.2 KB

Recessed Folding Handles - https://amzn.to/4mBUhhP We used an M12 cutoff tool to cut out holes in the sides of each drawer unit and then riveted with 3/16” rivets. image 556×416 77.2 KB

image 556×416 77.2 KB

image 556×416 77.2 KB

Labels: We used Dymo labels for the outside and Niimbot D10 for the small labels for each bin. We superglued the Niimbot labels as they don’t stick well to the 3D prints without it.

Labels: We used Dymo labels for the outside and Niimbot D10 for the small labels for each bin. We superglued the Niimbot labels as they don’t stick well to the 3D prints without it.

We modified the standard Gridfinity dimensions to fit these boxes on a nice grid. We achieved this by modifying two Onshape feature scripts to meet our specific needs. A bambu H2D (or H2S) can print the grids in two parts; the Bambu X1C (P series) needs to split them into 3, I believe.

image 982×562 90.9 KB

image 982×562 90.9 KB

Here is an example of a full stack with the organizer cases inside them. image 908×1083 116 KB

image 908×1083 116 KB

image 908×1083 116 KB

Below are all the cases we have created so far; several are incomplete and not well-organized yet. As we use them, we’ll fill them out and add labels, etc.

posts.name: Elliot S
posts.cooked:
AllenGregoryIV:

image 1345×904 147 KB

image 1345×904 147 KB

image 1345×904 147 KB

This looks amazing! I like the idea of using metal bins instead of the plastic ones, we have had trouble with those in the past. At the same time, those also look a lot bigger than most of the plastic organizers in that style. How heavy are these? I know the chain box we have with the large version of the plastic organizers is very heavy. How much are these when fully loaded? Can an average freshman carry one?

posts.name: AllenGregoryIV
posts.cooked:
A single case yes, they are heavy but not that bad.

The 4 stack drawer units, fully loaded, those can get over 100lbs, so they are a two person lift and we plan to make dollies for them so the only time we are lifting them is in and out of vehicles.

posts.name: Sam Geckler
posts.cooked:
Allen,

We’ve been working on a similar idea, but one thing that is keeping us from leaping into the Gridfinity space is SOMEONE always turns the bolt boxes on their side, or in the case of those metal boxes, holds it by the handle. Does your system prevent bolts from migrating between containers? I’ve stuck with lids that have indents to separate bins while closed.

posts.name: AllenGregoryIV
posts.cooked:
We’ve only had the system for a little bit, but when I made the bin heights I got them as close to the lid as possible.

So far they have passed our shake tests without the bolts moving between bins.

We may end up adding some rubber or foam to the lids to help seal them if it becomes a problem.

We also always train team members to not carry them sideways, it still happens sometimes but every 4-5 years someone does it with a plastic one and the latch wasn’t fully closed and everything drops, and people learn why we don’t hold them sideways.

The smaller handle on these discourage holding the cases that way anyway as the handles aren’t comfortable.

posts.name: Sam Geckler
posts.cooked: I guess the metal lids might be more rigid too. I like the idea of the bins being so tall to be right next to the closed lid. And I love a good shake test!!

posts.name: Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)
posts.cooked:
AllenGregoryIV:

We also always train team members to not carry them sideways, it still happens sometimes but every 4-5 years someone does it with a plastic one and the latch wasn’t fully closed and everything drops, and people learn why we don’t hold them sideways.

We’re still on the Harbor Freight bin train, but I’m watching with interest.

And also wondering if I should fire up the labelmaker to add “HOLD HERE” on each side of ours.

posts.cooked: “CARRY HERE” or “CARRY [FLAT/LEVEL/HORIZONTAL]” might be clearer and easier to understand for the people who need to learn (rather than merely remember).

posts.name: Sam Geckler
posts.cooked:
This begs a question to the community, what length bolts do you stock in your boxes? Certain sizes I’ve found not as useful. For example, 4926 doesn’t stock 2 or 3” length 10-32s because they seem to have limited usefulness when leaving 1/4” of thread for a typical Nyloc.

Here’s what’s in our 10-32 SHCS Box (and why) 0.50 - used on many cots systems 0.75 - Bolting two 1/4” things together 1.00 - Bolting a 1/2” thing to a 1/4” thing. 1.25 - Bolting two 1/2” things together 1.50  - Bolting 1/8” or 1/4” plate to the to a 1”x1” or 2” side of a 2”x1” 1.75  - Bolting a 1” thing to a 1/2” thing 2.25 - Bolting a 1”x1” to another 1”x1” 2.50 - Bolting 1/4” plate to the 1” side of a 2”x1” 2.75 - Bolting a 2” thing to a 1/2” thing 3.50 - Bolt a 2” to a 1” thing (Readily available from McMaster - 3.25 is not) 4.50 - Bolt 2” things together (Readily available from McMaster - 4.25 is not)

A 2” bolt could be useful to bolting a 1.5” thing to a 1/4” plate, but we just don’t seem to use 1.5” things very often. So we don’t stock 2” length bolts.

I could probably be convinced to stock 1/4” length bolts for some Cots replacement applications.

posts.name: AllenGregoryIV
posts.cooked:
sgeckler:

This begs a question to the community, what length bolts do you stock in your boxes?

Our goal was to stock as many of the bolts that REV and WCP sell as possible and I think we might have added a couple McMaster/BoltDepot only sizes too.

As weight becomes more of an issue on robots, we want to be able to use the right size bolt for every application and not have any that are too long, or need to special order in season.

One of the the advantages of the bins being this large is we have room for nearly every bolt length and head type, plus spacers, washers, nuts, etc.
